reviewText: Steve Martin, renaissance man - writer, author, comedian, playwright, screenwriter, producer, actor, banjo player extraordinaire - is more than deserving of his own Shout! Factory retrospective, and the label's wonderful STEVE MARTIN: THE TELEVISION STUFF ranks as one of the year's most enjoyable DVD catalog retrospectives.Available on September 18th, this three-disc set focuses primarily on the early Martin years, with his two taped concert performances and handful of network TV specials comprising the set's first two platters. Martin's stand-up is particularly noteworthy, seeing as he abandoned it in lieu of his feature-film career. In both a 1976 HBO special and a 1978 appearance at the Universal Ampitheatre (included in the 1984 home video special "Homage to Steve," along with the funny short "The Absent-Minded Waiter"), Martin shows off both his adroit comedy writing and a side of his on-screen "persona" that viewers unfamiliar with his early material will find especially amusing. Unlike other stand-up acts which haven't weathered the years well (including the Richard Pryor concert films, which I've seen recently on cable, and are almost entirely dependant on drug/shock humor that's no longer shocking), Martin's material is sly and offbeat, relying on his "performance" as a hapless magician and comedian to milk laughs out of intentionally-poor material.Martin moved on to a series of network TV specials before hitting it big as an `80s big-screen star - the 1978 effort "A Wild and Crazy Guy," 1980's "Comedy Is Not Pretty" and "All Commercials," and 1981's "Steve Martin's Best Show Ever" are all included here and work well within the confines of their genre, mostly comprised of SNL-like sketches with a series of guest stars appearing within (as Martin notes in a new interview split onto each of the three discs, the era of the star-driven network TV special was fading when he agreed to star in them). Disc three, meanwhile, is a self-described "Bits and Pieces" anthology of Martin appearances on SNL, Letterman, The Tonight Show, his Mark Twain acceptance speech from 2006, and even his first TV appearance in 1966 on "Dusty's Attic."It's a tremendous compilation of nostalgic - and occasionally hilarious - material from a gifted comedian that's well worth revisiting or, perhaps, discovering for the first time - especially among younger viewers who may only know Martin from limp "comedies" like the "Pink Panther" and "Cheaper By the Dozen" films (and if that's the only Steve Martin they know, then shame on them!).
summary: Classic Martin and One of the Year's Best DVD Retropsectives

reviewText: I watched a lot of this box set on my computer and it looked great but when I was ready to watch the classic concert from 1979 I put it in my DVD player. The picture quality was awful on my 42" flat screen. There was a lot of ghosting every time Steve moved and the overall picture looked kind of washed out. I was surprised at the poor quality. Turns out the entire set doesn't look very good unless I view it on my Windows media player on my computer. I rewatched the '79 concert this way and it looked sharp and clear. The contents are great as expected but I'm surprised none of it has been remastered. Shout Factory's stuff usually looks much better. So enjoy this set of classic comedy but watch it on your computer.
summary: 5 STARS FOR CONTENT, NOT FOR PICTURE QUALITY

Title: N/A

reviewText: I've been waiting for the first Steve Martin HBO special to become available, and while over 3 decades is a long time it was worth the wait. We went to see Steve at a local college right around the time the special came out on HBO, and he seemed stunned that the entire gymnasium audience knew his act by heart. It didn't make it any less funny to me, but I think that comedians learned around then that when they did their act for the HBO On Location series, they pretty much burned a lot of material.As for the package, it's very nicely presented and the low price I paid I would have gladly paid for the one hour HBO special, which showed the phenomena that was to become Steve Martin -  a stand-up comedian playing 18,000 seat arenas. The rest of the material is all gravy, and while it varies in quality, most shows an artist at his peak in both timing and material. Some has become dated, but most of it is very enjoyable. Highly recommended.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I don't understand why people who have not actually seen a product here on Amazon think it is useful to add a review.  Also, it is really not helpful to write a review that highlights that you made a mistake and can't read online descriptions.  This reveiw is for people who want to know what someone who actually owns the product thinks.I snatched this DVD set up as soon as I saw it because I am a long time Steve Martin fan.  I am extremely glad I did.  This is a wonderful set of never before available classic routines for Martin and all of them are treasures.  For those who are not big Steve Martin fans, you still might want to get this because it is a good illustration of a unique comedy style that is now a part of comedic history.The set does not include some of the already previously available spots like Saturday Night Live that Martin did.  That's okay with me because being a Steve Martin fan, I've already got these.  The only thing that should be a concern is whether or not Shout can meet the demand tht this set is sure to genterate.  I noticed that currently it says the DVD set will ship within 1 to 3 weeks.At the end of the day, this is a must have if you like Martin's style of comedy.  You will not be disappointed.  Highly recommended!
summary: A Must Have for Steve Martin Fans

reviewText: I can't wait for this DVD set!  I've always been a huge Steve Martin fan. Not only is he a hilarious comedian, but he's also a very respected musician (world-class banjo player), actor and screenwriter.  I feel like Steve Martin is a true Renaissance man who can do it all.According to the description and press release, this box set will include Steve Martin's specials that have never before been made available to the public.  These hidden gems include his only two stand-up performances that were ever recorded live, including his Universal Amphitheater set from 1979. It looks like the DVD set will feature hilarious specials from early in his career, like his first ever TV appearance on "Dusty's Attic,"  his Oscar-nominated short film "The Absent-Minded Waiter," photos, interviews and a booklet.This is going to be a must-own collection for any Steve Martin fan like myself.  I'm really excited to see these performances that will shed new light onto Steve Martin outside of the movie-star we all know.

reviewerName: Mark Arnold "movie/tv, comic book and animati...
reviewText: I bought this collection because of Steve Martin and specifically for the "Wild and Crazy Guy" special and "Steve Martin's Best Show Ever" special. The "Wild and Crazy Guy" special has been edited down to around 33 minutes. Steve himself says in the commentary that it's shorter due to the repetition of the live comedy section that appears in another special on the second disc. This is true.However, what he doesn't say is that further edits were made that seem to be due to music licensing issues and guest star issues. The segment where Steve takes the kids camping cuts out the part where they sing "camp" songs like "I Feel Pretty" and the Stive (sic) Variety Special segment cuts where Steve sings "I Can See Clearly Now" and then he crashes into a chandelier made out of clear plastic glasses. These were very amusing parts cut out.The third part cut out wasn't as funny, but featured Milton Berle, George Burns and Bob Hope. This part wasn't as funny, but it still didn't need to be edited out.Like I said, it was probably due to music rights and royalties due to the estates of the now deceased comedians.
summary: Beware! Wild and Crazy Guy special edited beyond concert footage!

reviewText: The box set is excellent. Most of is fine. But 3 things could of been added and deleted. Everything in it is great but The Wild and Crazy Guy special they edited the live parts AND SEGMENTS to make it 34 minutes long. Also those live segments flowed with the show and were DIFFERENT performances than Homage to Steve. You need a bootleg or a copy of the complete show to notice it. In the Comedy is not Pretty special is complete but in the original there was no LAUGH TRACK. Shout always seems to screw things up. It's better with no laugh track. When you watch a original copy it has a different comedic element without a stupid laugh track it was intentional. The rest of it I never seen and to me it seems like it was untouched. I think on the third disc they could of worked a little harder on adding a ton of MORE TV appearances from anything Steve was on. More Sat Night Live more Letterman more Carson etc etc etc. But There is enough in it. The tapes are starting to wear a little from age. HBO I thought was great as well Homage to Steve. I'm seeing Steve live with his band in a month , I last saw him in 1979 when I was 10 ( I was a huge fan then belonged to his offical fan club still have the posters and fanzine ) and that show was a thrill he played a week at that venue, I still own the ticket stub. The interview he did as a bonus I guess was long enough but then I could listen to him talk about the 70's for hours. Ever notice how thin he got in 1981. I gave the box a 5 but a 4 I really wanted to choose because of certain things that could of been dealt with better like leave the main two shows alone. I'll live with the" other copies " I have. Does anyone remember when Steve sang I can see clearly now the rain must fall down a staircase and crashes into a chandelier....... well it's gone.
summary: Fantastic Genius Box Set with a couple of flaws

reviewText: When I cracked this baby open , I was first wondering where the promised '79 concert in its entirety was and was fuming... until I found it buried in disc 2 after the Homage To Steve..so Excuuuuse Me!  I enjoyed that show in person and can say it brought back so many fond memories...I was around 21 when Steve Martin blew up big time as a stand up so he's my (Daniel Tosh, Dane Cook etc.) and holds a special place in my heart along with George Carlin. Steve actually ended up with the career that Carlin had wanted when he began in the late 50's early 60's which saw him move from being court jester to movie star but for my money Steve Martin has never touched in any of his movies the brilliance displayed on these 3 DVDs of lunacy...stupidity..and surprisingly intelligent comedy. Of course I also LOVE all the banjo playing. While I am so happy to have the '79 show I actually attended..the '76 show from the Troubadour was a total surprise (I didn't have HBO in '76 and didn't know anybody else who did) so this even earlier nugget filmed more in a club environment is the perfect opening show!Its a great mix of classic stand up and sketch comedy which is very much of its time but goodness when you have a Pre-Pee Wee Herman Paul Reubens a post Starsky & Hutch Antonio Vargas, classic Louie Nye...legendary writer Pat Proft and others like Richard Deacon and Peter Graves in your casts...you have a time capsule that is full of funny.the DVD quality is very good...best source material possible and Steve's bonus interview on each DVD is also current and appreciated as an extra...in particular there is an option to view the bonus disc with Steve giving a brief intro to each segment and it really adds a great deal to that set. It seems a bit pricy but this is a comedy treasure and deserves to be archived with the great old Carlin specials.I'd like to add a recommendation of another DVD I found on Amazon.com92Y-Steve Martin (December 9, 2007)This is an hour interview with Charlie Rose. Charlie isn't super helpful and steps on Steve many times but Steve Martin is so open in discussing his stand up years (this was a promotional appearance for his wonderful book "Born Standing Up"Born Standing Up: A Comic's Lifethat I found it the perfect companion to this wonderful 3 disc collection.
summary: a review from an owner of the set...

reviewText: Lots of bits and pieces -- some good, a couple meh (for example, The filmed version of "I Believe" is slow; Martin performed the piece much better live on SNL--timing in front of a live audience seems to helped--for another example an included TV show "All Commercials" is maybe better left buried. But there are plenty of gems and beyond that, the Live show and "Comedy is Not Pretty" special are each worth the price of the package. Quintessential Steve Martin stand up.
summary: The Two Long Shows are gems --worth the purchase
